TestDescription.name: PHP-CGI remote code execution
TestDescription.Description:
PHP is a widely-used general-purpose scripting language that is especially suited for Web development and can be embedded into HTML. When PHP is used in a CGI-based setup (such as Apache's mod_cgid), in some configurations it's possible to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the web server.
On Debian and Ubuntu the vulnerability is present in the default install of the php5-cgi package. When the php5-cgi package is installed on Debian and Ubuntu or php-cgi is installed manually the php-cgi binary is accessible under /cgi-bin/php5 and /cgi-bin/php. The vulnerability makes it possible to execute the binary because this binary has a security check enabled when installed with Apache http server and this security check is circumvented by the exploit.
[break] [break] [bold]Affected versions:[/bold][break] [ul] [li]PHP prior to 5.3.12[/li] [li]PHP prior to 5.4.2[/li] [/ul]
[break] [bold]Unaffected versions:[/bold][break] [ul] [li]PHP 4 - getopt parser unexploitable[/li] [li]PHP 5.3.12 and up[/li] [li]PHP 5.4.2 and up[/li] [/ul]
TestDescription.Impact: A remote unauthenticated attacker could obtain sensitive information, cause a denial of service condition or may be able to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the web server.
TestDescription.Recommendation: Upgrade to the latest versions of PHP (unaffected versions are PHP 5.3.12 and newer, PHP 5.4.2 and newer).
